images.caption: Figure 1.We proposeHiWave, a novel training-free approach for high-resolution image generation using pretrained diffusion models. While standard Stable Diffusion XL (SDXL) can produce globally coherent images, it lacks fine details when upscaled to 4096√ó\times√ó4096 resolution (left column). Existing training-free methods (e.g., Pixelsmith(Tragakis et¬†al.,2024)) enhance details in SDXL outputs but often introduce duplicated objects and visual artifacts (middle column). In contrast,HiWaveleverages a patch-wise DDIM inversion strategy combined with a wavelet-based detail enhancer module to produce high-quality images with rich details and minimal duplication artifacts. Figure 3.Overview of HiWave, our training-free high-resolution image generation pipeline. We first generate a base image using a pretrained model through a standard sampling process that transforms random noise (zTsubscriptùëßùëáz_{T}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) into a clean image (z~0subscript~ùëß0\tilde{z}_{0}over~ start_ARG italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) conditioned on a text prompt. This image is then upscaled in the image domain using Lanczos interpolation and encoded back into the latent space via the VAE encoder to enrich the base image with additional details. A patch-wise DDIM inversion process is then performed, mapping the upscaled image back to its corresponding noise representation. Finally, our DWT-based detail enhancement approach applies frequency-selective guidance during denoising, using wavelet decomposition to independently control low-frequency structure and guide high-frequency components for finer details. Skip residuals are also incorporated during the early sampling steps to further preserve the global coherence of the base image. This pipeline enables HiWave to generate high-quality, high-resolution images without duplications.

Figure 5.Comparison between our HiWave method at 4096√ó\times√ó4096 resolution (left) and the SDXL base model at 1024√ó\times√ó1024 resolution (right). Each row displays a different image along with corresponding zoomed-in regions to highlight detail enhancement. Row 1 features a porcelain bottle with intricate blue patterns; Row 2 shows a knitted toy mouse with clearly visible yarn texture; and Row 3 depicts a child in a flower field, with enhanced hair and fabric details. The zoomed regions illustrate how HiWave preserves the overall composition generated by SDXL while significantly enhancing fine details that are only partially present in the original generations.

Figure 7.Qualitative comparison of high-resolution (4096√ó\times√ó4096) image generation across three methods. Figure 9.Failure example of current metrics in evaluating high-resolution images. The left image (HiWave w/o DWT) contains visible duplication artifacts, including a hallucinated couple in the trees and a disembodied hand in the grass. In contrast, the DWT-guided HiWave result (right) is clean and artifact-free. Despite this clear perceptual difference, common metrics faile to reflect the quality gap. ImageReward scores are 0.0443 vs 0.0168, respectively.
